description: Borrowed from Latin campus (“field”). Doublet of camp.
First used in its current sense in reference to Princeton University in the 1770s.

entries.meaning: The grounds or property of a school, college, university, business, church, or hospital, often understood to include buildings and other structures.
examples: The campus is sixty hectares in size.

entries.meaning: An institution of higher education and its ambiance.
examples: During the late 1960s, many an American campus was in a state of turmoil.

verbs.description: campus (third-person singular simple present campuses or campusses, present participle campusing or campussing, simple past and past participle campused or campussed)

entries.meaning: To confine (a student) to campus as a punishment.
(climbing) To use a campus board, or to climb without feet as one would on a campus board.
examples: It is climbed or "campused" with only your arms and hands.
